item.title: New website features

item.title: Who was William L. Iams (1872-1896)?
item.description: At the young age of 20 years old, while deployed as a member of the Pennsylvania Reserves, William Iams made an ill-advised cheer. What immediately followed was his torture by his own commanders nearly to the point of unconsciousness, literal tar and feathering out of camp, dismissal from the Army, and an national news spectacle with court-room drama. And ultimately, his violent death only four years later.

item.title: Who was Raleigh Brown Ijams (1858-1907)?
item.description: Raleigh Brown Ijams was born into a wealthy family in modern day West Virginia, raised in Baltimore and later lived in Manhattan. He engaged in a variety of business ventures. He never married, nor had any children, and died at a relatively young age of 48. Fortunately, through his appreciation of a young Helen Keller, we learn much more about Raleigh.

Analysis and Summary of the Will of William Burgess (1622â€“1686)

The following is a detailed analysis and summary of the 1685 Will of William Burgess of Anne Arundel County, Maryland.

Summary of William Burgess’s Will

William Burgess’s will, dated 11 July 1685, provides extensive instructions concerning his religious beliefs, burial wishes, debts, and the distribution of his substantial estate among family members, friends, and a servant. It shows careful planning for the financial security of his wife, Ursula, and provisions for his children’s inheritances.
